note: Course/unit descriptions sourced from College Board AP course pages (see per-course sources). Each unit entry uses College Board wording 'Topics may include' where applicable.

courses.overview: Single-variable calculus emphasizing limits, derivatives, integrals, differential equations, and applications; organized into 8 commonly taught units.
courses.important_notes: AP Calculus AB scope only—no BC-only topics like series, Taylor/Maclaurin, or polar/parametric integration. Use College Board notation, justify with MVT/IVT and FTC language, and keep modeling to single-variable calculus with clear units and context for rates of change.

units.description: Conceptual and computational foundations of limits and continuity; using limits to reason about instantaneous change and function behavior.
topics_may_include: Understanding limits conceptually and numerically; one-sided limits
Algebraic techniques for evaluating limits (factoring, conjugates)
Limits at infinity and horizontal asymptotes
Squeeze Theorem and limit proofs (informal)
Definition and properties of continuity; Intermediate Value Theorem

keywords: Derivatives of trig and log functions
units.description: Derivative as limit and instantaneous rate of change; basic derivative rules and interpretations.
topics_may_include: Definition of derivative at a point and as a function (limit of difference quotient)
Relationship between differentiability and continuity
Basic derivative rules for power, exponential, logarithmic, trigonometric functions
Derivative interpretation: velocity, slope of tangent
Using derivative notation and units

units.unit_title: Differentiation: Composite, Implicit, and Inverse Functions
units.description: Techniques for differentiating more complex functions including chain rule, implicit differentiation, and higher-order derivatives.
topics_may_include: Chain rule for composite functions
Implicit differentiation and related rates
Derivatives of inverse functions
Higher-order derivatives and interpretation (concavity, jerk)
Applications of differentiation rules in multiple representations

units.description: Modeling and solving real-world problems using derivatives: rates, optimization, and interpretation of derivatives in context.
topics_may_include: Instantaneous rate of change in applications
Related rates problems
Interpreting derivative sign, increasing/decreasing behavior
Linearization and differentials
Use of derivatives to model motion and growth/decay

units.description: Techniques for analyzing function behavior using derivatives: extrema, Mean Value Theorem, curve sketching.
topics_may_include: Critical points, local/global extrema
First and second derivative tests
Mean Value Theorem and Rolle’s Theorem
Sketching graphs using limits, derivatives, asymptotes, and concavity
Applications to optimization problems

units.description: Definite and indefinite integrals, Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, accumulation functions, and antiderivative techniques.
topics_may_include: Definite integrals as limits of Riemann sums and accumulated change
Fundamental Theorem of Calculus (parts I & II)
Antiderivatives and indefinite integrals
Integration techniques: substitution, basic integrals
Area between curves and interpretation of integrals in context

units.description: Solving and interpreting simple differential equations; growth/decay models, slope fields, and separable equations.
topics_may_include: Separable differential equations and solving initial value problems
Slope (direction) fields and qualitative solution behavior
Exponential growth and decay models
Differential equation modeling of context-based rates of change
Using integrals to solve accumulation/area problems arising from differential equations

units.description: Applied uses of integration: volumes, average value, accumulation in physical contexts and additional applied problem solving.
topics_may_include: Volumes of revolution (disk/washer, shell methods—basic)
Average value of a function on an interval
Accumulated change in physics/economics contexts
Work and net change applications (basic)
Integration in motion problems (position/velocity/acceleration)

courses.overview: All AP Calculus AB content plus extended topics: parametric/vector functions, polar coordinates, and infinite sequences and series; organized into 10 commonly taught units.
courses.important_notes: Include BC-specific content: parametric/polar calculus, vector motion, Taylor/Maclaurin series, power series convergence tests, and error bounds. Calculus must use derivatives and integrals; keep within single-variable contexts and avoid multivariable/linear algebra.

units.description: Same foundational limit and continuity concepts as AB with emphasis on readiness for series and advanced function behaviors.
topics_may_include: Limit computations, continuity, asymptotic behavior
One-sided limits and limits at infinity
Applications toward series convergence tests

units.description: Derivative definitions and basic rules extended to functions needed for later BC topics.
topics_may_include: Derivative as limit, basic derivative rules, differentiability vs continuity

units.unit_title: Differentiation: Composite, Implicit, and Inverse Functions
units.description: Advanced differentiation techniques (chain rule, implicit), preparing for parametric and polar derivatives.
topics_may_include: Chain rule, implicit differentiation, inverse function derivatives
Higher-order derivatives and applications

units.description: Applied derivative problems, optimization, and modeling in varied contexts.
topics_may_include: Related rates, optimization, modeling with derivatives

units.description: Function analysis, curve sketching, and theorems about derivatives.
topics_may_include: Extrema, Mean Value Theorem, concavity and inflection points

units.description: Definite/indefinite integrals, Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, and integration techniques.
topics_may_include: Riemann sums, FTC, u-substitution, applications to accumulation

units.description: Separable and other first-order differential equations and applications including logistic growth; slope fields.
topics_may_include: Separable ODEs, exponential/logistic growth, slope fields

units.description: Applied integration problems including advanced volume and physical applications.
topics_may_include: Volumes by slicing/shells, work, arc length (introductory contexts)

units.unit_title: Parametric Equations, Polar Coordinates, and Vector-Valued Functions
units.description: Representation and calculus for parametric, polar, and vector functions; derivatives and integrals in these systems.
topics_may_include: Parametric equations: derivatives, arc length, area
Polar coordinates: r(θ), area and slope in polar
Vector-valued functions, velocity and acceleration in parametric form

units.description: Convergence tests and power series including Taylor and Maclaurin series and approximations.
topics_may_include: Sequences and infinite series, geometric series
Tests for convergence: nth-term, integral, comparison, ratio, alternating series
Power series, radius/interval of convergence
Taylor and Maclaurin series and polynomial approximations

courses.overview: Introductory, non-calculus college-level statistics course organized into nine commonly taught units (note: College Board announced future revisions for 2026–27).
courses.important_notes: Always keep answers in context of the study. State conditions (randomization, independence, normal/large n) before inference; use correct symbols (p, μ, \hat{p}, \bar{x}), hypotheses, and interpretations of p-values/intervals. No calculus; rely on AP-approved inference procedures and clear communication of conclusions.

units.description: Fundamentals of describing and summarizing distributions of single variables; central tendency, spread, and graphical displays.
topics_may_include: Types of variables (categorical vs quantitative)
Graphical displays: histograms, dotplots, stemplots, bar charts
Measures of center and spread (mean, median, IQR, standard deviation)
Shape descriptions, outliers, and robust statistics
Normal distribution and z-scores

units.description: Analyzing relationships between two variables using association measures and models.
topics_may_include: Comparing two categorical variables (contingency tables)
Scatterplots, correlation coefficient (r)
Least-squares regression, interpreting slope and intercept
Residuals and diagnostics, departures from linearity

units.description: Principles of study design, sampling methods, and sources of bias to support valid inference.
topics_may_include: Sampling designs: simple random, stratified, cluster, multistage
Experiments vs observational studies, randomization, control, blocking
Bias, confounding, and ethical considerations
Designing studies to support causal inference when appropriate

units.unit_title: Probability, Random Variables, and Probability Distributions
units.description: Probability rules and modeling randomness with discrete and continuous distributions as foundation for inference.
topics_may_include: Probability rules (addition, multiplication, conditional probability, independence)
Random variables, expectation, variance
Binomial and geometric distributions (and applications)
Law of large numbers and use of simulation

keywords: Type I and Type II errors
units.description: Sampling variability and the Central Limit Theorem; sampling distributions of statistics as basis for inference.
topics_may_include: Sampling distribution of a sample mean and sample proportion
Central Limit Theorem and its conditions
Standard error and interpretation
Bias vs sampling variability

units.description: Confidence intervals and hypothesis tests for proportions including comparing two proportions.
topics_may_include: Constructing and interpreting confidence intervals for a proportion
One- and two-sample proportion tests (z-tests)
p-value interpretation and Type I/II errors
Conditions for validity of methods

units.description: CI and hypothesis testing for means and comparing two means (t-procedures where appropriate).
topics_may_include: t-distribution and one-sample t procedures
Two-sample t-tests and pooled/unpooled reasoning
Confidence intervals for means and mean differences
Assumptions and robustness

units.description: Chi-square tests for goodness-of-fit, homogeneity, and independence for categorical data analysis.
topics_may_include: Chi-square goodness-of-fit test
Chi-square test of independence and homogeneity
Selecting appropriate categorical inference procedures
Interpreting chi-square statistics and limitations

units.description: Inference about the slope in regression models: confidence intervals and hypothesis tests for slope.
topics_may_include: Inference for slope using t-distribution
Interpreting slope as estimated effect
Conditions for regression inference

courses.overview: Introductory college-level programming using a subset of Java; revised framework (effective 2025–26) organizes content into 4 units emphasizing objects, control structures, class creation, and data collections.
courses.important_notes: Use Java only with the AP subset: classes/objects, inheritance basics, arrays/ArrayList, recursion, and control structures. Avoid libraries beyond java.lang and java.util.ArrayList; no lambdas/streams or GUI/IO. Use standard AP Java syntax and avoid AP CSP pseudocode.

units.description: Fundamentals of Java, objects, methods, primitive types, and basic API usage.
topics_may_include: Primitive types (int, double, boolean) and expressions
Variables, assignment, evaluation order
Creating and using objects and calling methods
String objects and common String methods
Static methods (Math) and simple I/O

units.description: Control flow: conditionals and loops for algorithm implementation and problem solving.
topics_may_include: if, if-else, nested conditionals
for, while, do-while loops and loop invariants
Combining selection and iteration to implement algorithms
Debugging and tracing control flow

units.description: Designing classes, constructors, instance variables, methods, and encapsulation (object-oriented basics as required by the course).
topics_may_include: Defining classes with fields and methods
Constructors, overloading, and object state
Access control, instance vs class (static) members
Designing methods to implement behavior and abstraction

units.description: Using and implementing common data structures and algorithms to store and process collections of data.
topics_may_include: Arrays and array processing algorithms
ArrayList and other collection usage patterns
Searching and sorting basics (selection, insertion, simple sorts)
Traversing and manipulating collections; iteration patterns
Text files and datasets (added in 2025–26 revisions)

courses.overview: Introductory computing course covering breadth of computer science: creativity, data, algorithms/programming, systems/networks, and societal impact.
courses.important_notes: Use AP CSP pseudocode (not Java/JavaScript). Emphasize abstraction, algorithms, data representation, the internet, cybersecurity, and computing impacts. Keep math light; focus on reasoning about algorithms, data, and societal context rather than language-specific syntax.

units.title: Creative Development
units.description: Design and development process for computational artifacts; decomposition and abstraction in problem solving.
topics_may_include: Problem definition and ideation
Design methodology and development cycles
Abstraction to manage complexity
Creating computational artifacts and portfolios

units.title: Data
units.description: Using data to discover knowledge: collection, representation, analysis, and ethical considerations.
topics_may_include: Data collection and sampling considerations
Data representation (tables, visualizations) and transformation
Analyzing data to draw conclusions, data-driven decision making
Privacy, security, and ethical uses of data

units.title: Algorithms and Programming
units.description: Core algorithmic thinking and programming constructs to develop and evaluate solutions.
topics_may_include: Algorithm design and problem decomposition
Programming constructs: variables, control flow, procedures/functions
Testing, debugging, and algorithmic efficiency (basic)
Implementing algorithms to solve computational problems

units.title: Computer Systems and Networks
units.description: Fundamentals of how computing systems operate and how networks enable distributed computing.
topics_may_include: Hardware vs software, system architecture basics
How networks and the internet transmit data
Representation of data in binary and abstractions built on it

units.title: Impact of Computing
units.description: Social, ethical, and economic impacts of computing and how computing innovations shape society.
topics_may_include: Positive and negative societal impacts of computing
Ethics, privacy, equity, and intellectual property
Evaluation of claims about computing technologies

courses.overview: Two-semester, college-level biology course for majors; organized into 8 commonly taught units covering chemistry of life through ecology and evolution.
courses.important_notes: Frame questions around experimental or data-based scenarios; emphasize evolution/natural selection evidence, energy transfer, cell communication, and gene expression/regulation. Use correct biology terminology and simple quantitative tools (chi-square, Hardy–Weinberg reasoning) without heavy math. Avoid anatomy trivia not in the framework. Avoid Chemistry and physics equations and instead focus on biological concepts.

keywords: pH concepts, not equations or equilibria
units.description: Biochemical foundations: water properties, macromolecules, and chemical reactions vital to living systems.
topics_may_include: Properties of water, pH, buffers
Structure and function of macromolecules: carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, nucleic acids
Basic energetics of biochemical reactions

keywords: Membrane structure, passive and active transport
units.description: Cell structure and function, membranes, transport, and cellular organization.
topics_may_include: Prokaryotic vs eukaryotic cell structure
Membrane structure, passive and active transport
Organelles and cellular compartmentalization

units.description: Metabolic pathways: photosynthesis, cellular respiration, and energy transfer.
topics_may_include: Glycolysis, Krebs cycle, oxidative phosphorylation
Light-dependent and light-independent reactions of photosynthesis
ATP, enzymes, and regulation of metabolic pathways

units.description: Signal transduction, cell-to-cell communication, and regulation of cell division.
topics_may_include: Signal reception, transduction pathways, second messengers
Cell cycle phases, checkpoints, mitosis and meiosis overview
Apoptosis and cancer basics

units.description: Mendelian genetics, inheritance patterns, and chromosomal basis of heredity.
topics_may_include: Mendelian crosses, probability in inheritance
Complex inheritance: linked genes, sex linkage, epistasis
Chromosomal abnormalities and pedigree analysis

units.description: Molecular genetics: DNA structure/function, transcription, translation, and regulation.
topics_may_include: DNA replication, transcription, RNA processing
Translation, genetic code, mutations
Gene regulation mechanisms (prokaryotes/eukaryotes), biotechnology basics

units.description: Evolutionary mechanisms, population genetics, speciation, and phylogenetics.
topics_may_include: Natural selection, genetic drift, gene flow, mutation
Hardy–Weinberg equilibrium and application
Speciation processes and evolutionary trees

units.description: Interactions among organisms and with their environments, ecosystems, energy flow, and conservation.
topics_may_include: Ecosystem structure and energy transfer (food webs, trophic levels)
Population ecology, carrying capacity, and community interactions
Biogeochemical cycles and human impacts on ecosystems

courses.overview: One-year introductory college general chemistry course organized into 9 commonly taught units spanning atomic to electrochemical concepts.
courses.important_notes: Use particulate representations and balanced units; emphasize stoichiometry, thermodynamics, equilibrium, kinetics, electrochemistry, and acid–base behavior. Distinguish strong vs weak electrolytes and typical lab/graph interpretations; avoid organic mechanisms and graduate-level quantum details.

units.description: Atomic theory, electron configuration, periodic trends, and mole concept.
topics_may_include: Atomic models, quantum numbers, electron configuration
Periodic trends: ionization energy, electronegativity, atomic radius
Mole concept and molar mass; mass spectrometry basics

units.description: Bonding theories and molecular structure as determinants of physical and chemical properties.
topics_may_include: Ionic vs covalent bonding, Lewis structures, resonance
VSEPR theory, hybridization, molecular polarity
Intermolecular forces and solids/liquids properties

units.description: States of matter, solutions, colligative properties, and phase behavior.
topics_may_include: Gas laws and kinetic molecular theory
Properties of liquids and solids, phase changes
Solutions, concentration units, solubility, colligative properties

units.description: Types of chemical reactions, stoichiometry, and quantitative reaction analysis.
topics_may_include: Balancing chemical equations, reaction stoichiometry
Limiting reagent, percent yield, reaction classification (redox, acid–base, precipitation)

units.description: Rates of reaction, rate laws, reaction mechanisms, and factors affecting rates.
topics_may_include: Rate laws and reaction order determination
Collision theory, activation energy, temperature dependence (Arrhenius concept)
Interpretation of rate data and mechanism inference

units.description: Energy changes in chemical processes, enthalpy, calorimetry, and heat transfer.
topics_may_include: Endothermic vs exothermic processes, enthalpy changes
Calorimetry and heat capacity calculations
Hess’s Law and enthalpy of formation

units.description: Chemical equilibrium concepts, equilibrium constants, Le Chatelier’s principle.
topics_may_include: Equilibrium constant expressions (Kc, Kp)
Solving equilibrium problems, ICE tables
Le Chatelier’s principle and shifts in equilibrium

units.description: Acid–base theories, pH/pOH calculations, titrations, buffers, and polyprotic species.
topics_may_include: Strong vs weak acids/bases, pH and pOH calculations
Buffer systems and Henderson–Hasselbalch equation
Titration curves and equivalence point analysis

units.description: Entropy, Gibbs free energy, spontaneity, and redox electrochemistry including galvanic/electrolytic cells.
topics_may_include: Entropy and Gibbs free energy; relationship to equilibrium
Electrochemical cells: cell notation, standard reduction potentials
Calculations of cell potential and Faraday’s laws (basic)

courses.overview: Algebra-based introductory college-level physics covering mechanics and basic waves/fluids, organized into 8 commonly taught units.
courses.important_notes: Algebra-based only—no calculus. Emphasize free-body diagrams, sign conventions, unit consistency, and qualitative reasoning. Focus on kinematics/dynamics, energy/momentum, rotation/torque, SHM, waves, and basic circuits/fluids; avoid AP Physics 2 or C-only topics.

keywords: Kinematic equations (v = v0 + a t; Δx = v0 t + 1/2 a t^2; v^2 = v0^2 + 2 a Δx)
units.description: Describing motion in one and two dimensions: displacement, velocity, acceleration, and representations. Use 10 for gravity.
topics_may_include: Scalars and vectors, displacement vs distance
Constant and variable acceleration motion equations
Projectile motion and relative motion
Graphical representations of motion

units.description: Newton’s laws, free-body diagrams, friction, circular motion, and dynamics of systems.
topics_may_include: Newton’s three laws of motion
Free-body diagrams and solving force problems
Friction (static and kinetic), tension, normal force
Circular motion and centripetal acceleration

units.description: Work–energy theorem, kinetic/potential energy, conservation of energy, and power calculations.
topics_may_include: Work definition and calculation
Kinetic and potential energy, conservative forces
Energy conservation and energy diagrams
Power and energy transfer

units.description: Momentum, impulse, and conservation in collisions (elastic and inelastic).
topics_may_include: Linear momentum and impulse
Momentum conservation in isolated systems
Elastic vs inelastic collisions and center-of-mass concepts

units.description: Rotational kinematics and dynamics: torque, rotational inertia, and rotational analogs of linear motion.
topics_may_include: Torque, lever arm, and rotational equilibrium
Moment of inertia concepts and angular acceleration
Relationship between torque and angular acceleration

units.unit_title: Energy and Momentum of Rotating Systems
units.description: Rotational energy, angular momentum, and conservation in rotating systems.
topics_may_include: Rotational kinetic energy, work by torques
Angular momentum and its conservation

units.description: Simple harmonic motion, pendulums, and mass–spring systems.
topics_may_include: Simple harmonic motion equations and energy in oscillators
Period and frequency of mass–spring systems and pendulums
Damping and qualitative behavior

units.description: Fluid statics and dynamics including pressure, buoyancy, and continuity/Bernoulli applications.
topics_may_include: Pressure and hydrostatic laws
Archimedes’ principle and buoyant force
Continuity equation and Bernoulli’s principle (qualitative)

courses.overview: Continuation of algebra-based physics focusing on fluids, thermodynamics, electricity, magnetism, optics, waves, and modern physics; organized into seven commonly taught units.
courses.important_notes: Algebra-based only—no calculus. Cover fluids, thermo, electrostatics, circuits (RC), magnetism, optics, waves, and introductory modern physics. Use correct units and sign conventions; keep math to algebra/trig and avoid Physics C-style derivations.

units.description: Heat, temperature, heat transfer, and the laws of thermodynamics.
topics_may_include: Temperature vs heat, calorimetry
First law of thermodynamics and internal energy
Heat engines and efficiency (qualitative)

units.description: Electrostatics: Coulomb’s law, electric field and potential, and superposition.
topics_may_include: Coulomb’s law and electric field calculations
Electric potential and potential energy of charge configurations
Conductors and insulators (qualitative)

units.description: DC circuit analysis: current, resistance, Ohm’s law, series and parallel networks.
topics_may_include: Ohm’s law, Kirchhoff’s rules (basic)
Series and parallel resistor networks
Capacitors in circuits (qualitative and basic quantitative)

units.description: Magnetic fields, forces on moving charges and currents, and basic electromagnetic induction principles.
topics_may_include: Magnetic field of currents, force on moving charges
Biot–Savart and right-hand rule (qualitative use)
Electromagnetic induction overview (Faraday, Lenz)

units.description: Ray optics: reflection, refraction, lenses, mirrors, and image formation.
topics_may_include: Law of reflection and refraction (Snell’s law)
Lens and mirror equations, magnification
Ray tracing for simple systems

units.description: Wave properties, interference, superposition, standing waves, and sound.
topics_may_include: Wave parameters: wavelength, frequency, speed, amplitude
Interference and superposition, standing waves
Sound waves, Doppler effect (qualitative)

units.description: Introductory modern physics topics such as quantum phenomena and atomic models.
topics_may_include: Photoelectric effect and particle–wave duality (introductory)
Atomic models and basic nuclear concepts

courses.overview: Calculus-based mechanics course covering kinematics, Newtonian dynamics, energy, momentum, rotation, oscillations; commonly taught as college first-semester physics for STEM majors.
courses.important_notes: Calculus-based: derivatives/integrals are appropriate. Emphasize vector notation, sign conventions, and free-body diagrams. Focus on mechanics topics (kinematics, dynamics, energy, momentum, rotation, oscillations, gravitation) and avoid electricity/magnetism content here.

units.description: Position, velocity, and acceleration in one and two dimensions with calculus-based formulations.
topics_may_include: Vector kinematics, projectile motion with calculus
Differential relations among position, velocity, acceleration

units.description: Newton’s laws applied with calculus; forces, center of mass, circular motion, and gravitation.
topics_may_include: Newton’s laws in calculus form, free-body diagrams
Systems and center of mass, gravitation, circular dynamics

units.description: Work–energy theorem, potential energy functions, and conservation principles using calculus.
topics_may_include: Work integrals, conservative forces, energy conservation
Gravitational/elastic potential energy and work–energy relationships

units.unit_title: Systems of Particles and Linear Momentum
units.description: Momentum conservation for particles and systems, collisions, and impulse with calculus-based treatment.
topics_may_include: Linear momentum, impulse, center-of-mass motion
Elastic and inelastic collisions in one and two dimensions

units.description: Rotational kinematics and dynamics, torque, moment of inertia, and rotational energy.
topics_may_include: Angular kinematics, torque, rotational analogs of Newton’s laws
Moment of inertia calculations and rotational kinetic energy

units.description: Simple harmonic motion and gravitational systems analyzed with calculus tools.
topics_may_include: Simple harmonic motion derivations, pendulums, energy in oscillators
Orbital motion and gravitational potential in calculus context

courses.overview: Calculus-based course on electrostatics, circuits, magnetism, and electromagnetic induction; typically taught as second-semester calculus-based physics.
courses.important_notes: Calculus-based: line/surface integrals and derivatives are appropriate. Emphasize Gauss’s/Ampère’s laws, potential/field relationships, RC transients, induction (Faraday/Lenz), and field superposition. Use vector notation and units; avoid optics/modern physics which belong to Physics 2.

units.unit_title: Electric Charges, Fields, and Gauss's Law
units.description: Coulomb’s law, electric field computations, and application of Gauss’s Law to symmetric charge distributions.
topics_may_include: Coulomb’s law and superposition for point charges
Electric field of continuous charge distributions (calculus-based)
Electric flux and Gauss’s Law applications

units.description: Electric potential and potential energy due to charge distributions; work and energy perspectives.
topics_may_include: Electric potential of point charges and continuous distributions
Relation between electric field and potential (gradients), potential energy

units.description: Behavior of conductors, charging, capacitors, dielectrics, and related energy storage concepts.
topics_may_include: Electrostatics in conductors, shielding, surface charge distribution
Parallel plate capacitors, capacitance, dielectrics, energy stored in capacitors

units.description: DC circuit analysis including capacitance and energy considerations; calculus where needed for charge/current relationships.
topics_may_include: Current, resistance, Ohm’s law; RC circuits and transient analysis
Series and parallel circuits and energy calculations

units.description: Magnetic forces on charges and currents, fields from currents, and Ampère/Biot–Savart laws.
topics_may_include: Lorentz force on moving charges, force on current-carrying wires
Magnetic field of a long straight wire, loop; Biot–Savart and Ampère’s Law (applications)

units.description: Faraday’s Law, Lenz’s Law, inductance, and basic AC/DC induction phenomena.
topics_may_include: Faraday’s Law of induction, induced emf, Lenz’s Law
Inductance, LR circuits, and energy in magnetic fields

courses.overview: Interdisciplinary environmental science course covering ecosystems, resources, pollution, and global change; organized into 9 commonly taught units.
courses.important_notes: Use real-world environmental data/graphs and common units (ppm, ppb, kWh, hectares). Emphasize systems thinking: energy flow, biogeochemical cycles, population dynamics, pollution sources/mitigation, and policy trade-offs. Calculations should be simple (rates, proportions); avoid heavy chemistry/physics derivations.

units.description: Ecosystem structure, energy flow, productivity, and biogeochemical cycles.
topics_may_include: Ecosystem concepts, food chains/webs, trophic levels
Primary productivity, energy transfer (10% rule)
Carbon, nitrogen, phosphorus, and water cycles

units.description: Importance of biodiversity, species interactions, and conservation principles.
topics_may_include: Species diversity and ecosystem services
Island biogeography, ecological tolerance, and resilience

units.description: Population ecology, growth models, carrying capacity, and human population dynamics.
topics_may_include: Population growth models (exponential, logistic)
Carrying capacity, population regulation, age structure

units.description: Geological processes, soil, freshwater resources, and resource cycling.
topics_may_include: Plate tectonics, rock cycle, soil formation
Water resources, groundwater, watershed management

units.description: Human uses of land and water, agriculture, urban development, and sustainability issues.
topics_may_include: Agricultural practices, irrigation, sustainable land use
Urbanization, land-use change, wetland and riparian impacts

units.description: Energy types, extraction, consumption patterns, and alternatives/renewables.
topics_may_include: Fossil fuels, nuclear energy, renewable energy sources
Energy efficiency, life-cycle impacts, and trade-offs

units.description: Air pollution sources, atmospheric chemistry, smog, and mitigation strategies.
topics_may_include: Primary and secondary pollutants, photochemical smog
Acid rain, indoor air pollution, control technologies

units.description: Pollution impacts on terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems, waste management, and remediation.
topics_may_include: Sources of pollution, point vs non-point sources
Solid waste disposal, sewage treatment, eutrophication, bioaccumulation

units.description: Large-scale environmental changes including climate change, ozone depletion, invasive species, and mitigation/adaptation.
topics_may_include: Climate change science, greenhouse gases, mitigation and adaptation
Ozone depletion, ocean acidification, invasive species and global impacts
